 L ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT AND HIGHER EDUCATION A. Post-Adjustment Economy and Employment Needs 1.1 Since Argentina has now emerged from the economic crisis of the late 1980s and has established a more solid base for sustainable development, the Government is turning its attention to addressing the large social deficits that if unattended could slow economic progress. Within the social sectors, the role of the education system in supplying the human resources required for faster economic growth and successful competition in global markets is crucial. As the economy shifts to more outward-looking policies, and attempts to integrate itself into Mercosur and other international markets, concern has heightened for developing a well-educated, highly-skilled and flexible labor force which, given the relatively high wage level, will allow the country to compete in the production of high value-added products and services. 1.2 In the next decade, two major trends will affect employment: (i) an expected strong expansion of the labor force in Argentina (over two percent growth per year), due to the growth of the working-age population which should exceed overall population growth (reversing a tendency which has been predominant since World War II) and an increasing participation of women (the current women's labor force participation level of 26 percent is low compared to countries with a similar level of development and the rest of Latin America); and (ii) a dramatic shift in employment as a consequence of the economic crisis and the restructuring and modernization of the economy. As a result, tensions in the labor market are expected to remain high. Unemployment in May 1994 was 10.8 percent (1.4 million unemployed out of an active population of 13 million) and has disproportionately affected young people and people with no education. Fifty percent of the unemployed are less than 25 years old, and in October 1993 in Greater Buenos Aires the unemployment level was 9.7 percent, but 11.1 percent for people without instruction compared to 11.4 percent for those having completed the primary level, 8.1 percent secondary and 3.5 percent higher education.' Although the share of large companies in total employment remains significant (15.5 percent of those employed are in firms of over 100 employees, and 34 percent are in firms of between 6 and 100 employees) there is a steady trend toward rising employment in small-scale enterprises (50 percent), and self-employment in the informal sector. The manufacturing sectors are declining, while services are employing a growing share (presently 65 percent) of total employment. Finally, Argentinean industry is characterized by a steady growth of productivity and profound sectoral changes in which competitive industries are booming and those which were protected by trade barriers or were subsidized are declining. 1.3 As competition for jobs increases, the skill level and the mobility of the work force become even more important: (i) in a labor market which is becoming more flexible and competitive; (ii) for services which require a higher level of educational attainment (services employ 80 percent of those having a university diploma, and half of service sector employees have completed secondary education, compared with 27 percent in the 1. Encuesta de Hogares, INDEC, 1993.
 manufacturing sector); and (iii) to increase productivity in the existing industries and to favor the growth of more technological industries so that Argentina may remain competitive by counterbalancing the effects of high labor costs. Compared with neighboring countries, Argentina has the highest labor taxes and non-wage labor costs (48 percent compared to 38 percent in Brazil and 25 percent in Chile). Education Sector 1.4 Until the mid-1970s, Argentina had one of Latin America's most developed educational systems in terms of enrollment rates. Since 1980, there has been a dramatic expansion in access to schooling. Argentina has nearly attained universal primary education (primary education net enrollment ratio was 90 percent in 1991); secondary school net enrollment rate is 56 percent and about 20 percent of the age group 20 to 25 is in higher education.2 As a result, the Argentinean work force compares favorably relative to other countries of the region. In 1993, 8.6 percent of the working-age population had a higher education level, 27.1 percent secondary education, 54.9 percent a primary level of education and 9.3 percent had no education. On the average, women have a higher educational level than men.3 1.5 Argentina's population is less schooled, however, than those of countries with similar income levels. For instance, in 1985, although the average schooling years of Argentines over 25 years old was 6.6 (exceeding the LAC average of 4.4 years), Korea and Taiwan averaged 7.9 and 7.0 years respectively.4 Moreover, as a consequence of years of neglect and low and misdirected investment, the quality of the system has deteriorated. In secondary education, students' lack of learning is particularly acute. A 1992 survey carried out in Buenos Aires shows that in mathematics, on a scale of 0 to 6, 80 percent of secondary students scored under 3, and 22 percent scored 0. In Spanish, these proportions were 49 percent and 15 percent respectively. A 1993 nationwide survey showed that 40 percent of the students who completed secondary education did not read and write correctly. Hgher education's quality is declining as well, hampering Argentina's ability to compete internationally. Compared to Korea, Argentina's higher education system produces one-fourth fewer graduates per million inhabitants. The number of graduates is stagnating (33,000), and in some disciplines the situation is catastrophic: in 1993 only 40 students received a Master's degree in mathematics, 75 in physics, 65 in biology and 193 in computer sciences. 2.  -3 - Higher Education 1.6 From 1981 to 1991, enrollment in higher education grew at an average rate of 7.4 percent, particularly after the 1984 reform which provided open admission to all secondary school graduates and allowed some disciplines (mainly humanities), to reopen as a result of the democratization process (see Annex L Graph 1). More recently, there has been a decrease of new entrants into national universities due essentially to underinvestment and low quality at the secondary level. Argentina's higher education sector currently has about 1.1 million students. This number is an approximation because statistics on enrollment provided by higher education institutions do not distinguish between active and non-active students. As part of the Education Ministry's efforts to improve planning mechanisms, a census was undertaken in September 1994; first results revealed that 615,796 students are enrolled in national universities. 1.7 The higher education sector consists of 75 universities (33 national, 5 provincial and 37 private); about 1,000 teacher training institutes; and about 500 technical institutes. While non-university institutions have increased their combined share (from 19 percent to 24 percent), more than three-quarters of students are enrolled in universities. Enrollment in the private sector represents a small share (13 percent) compared to neighboring countries (Brazil 60 percent, Paraguay 40 percent, Chile 30 percent, Ecuador 26 percent). Enrollment in private universities has been increasing, from 81,000 in 1983 to 101,000 students in 1992, whereas at national universities it has more than doubled, from 338,000 to 699,000 students. Since the 1993 decree opening higher education to private initiatives, however, 15 new private institutions have been created and enrollment in public universities is stagnating. 1.8 During the past decade, the relative importance of academic disciplines in public universities has changed dramatically. Natural sciences and engineering declined significantly (in total enrollment from 46 percent in 1982 to 36 percent in 1992, and among new entrants from 49 to 33 percent), while the social sciences are increasing their share (in total enrollment from 31 to 36 percent, and among new entrants from 29 percent to 40 percent). The relative shares of medical sciences (14.6 percent of enrollment and 14.1 percent of new entrants) and humanities (respectively 12.9 percent and 13.1 percent) are more stable (see Annex I). 1.9 Among national universities, eight major universities account for 80 percent of total enrollment and 85 percent of graduates. While the average size of national universities is about 24,000 students, the number of students at each university varies considerably, from 869 at the UniversidadNacional de Quilmes to 169,540 at the Universidad Nacional de Buenos Aires which represents 24 percent of enrollment and 34 percent of graduates.' The disparities are even larger at the post-graduate level. This dispersion can be attributed to two factors: disparities between provinces and the concentration of population and economic activities in the metropolitan areas of Buenos
 - 4 - Aires; and government policy to establish at least one national university in each province regardless of population size (see Annex I, Table 1). 1.10 There is little reliable information on the socioeconomic background of students. However, the fact that more than 45 percent of the students' parents have less than secondary education shows the intergenerational progress. The Argentine university system is fairly gender-neutral. In public universities there are significantly more women students, new entrants and graduates (about 56 percent). On the other hand, the system appears to be economically inequitable. According to the 1994 census, 22 percent of students come from private secondary schools. Tuition-free higher education does not provide needy students with financial assistance for living expenses or purchase of learning materials. As a result, a significant proportion of students are forced to take employment, and proceed with part-time enrollment. More than half of the students have a job, 24 percent depend fully on this job for their living expenses, 29 percent mix resources from their parents and from their job. Only 0.3 percent are fully supported by a scholarship and 1.6 percent benefit from scholarships and resources from their parents. 1.11 During the last decade, the number of teaching positions has almost paralleled enrollment growth, doubling during the past decade from a little less than 53,000 in 1982 to over 101,000 in 1992. This makes the student/teacher ratio less than 7. However, considering the high percentage of part-time (67.4 percent) and half-time (21.2 percent) positions, the full-time equivalent ratio is estimated to be in the neighborhood of 13, a number which is closer to international standards. There are disparities among universities: the students/full-time equivalent teaching staff ratio tends to exceed 25 in the largest and most attractive universities, and to be lower in smaller universities, 6-8 on the average. 1.12 While the administration of primary and secondary education has been transferred to the provinces (in 1978 and 1992, respectively), the Ministry of Culture and Education (MCE) now has more significant responsibilities in higher education. A Secretariat for University Policies (Secretaria de Politicas Universitarias - SUP) was created in March 1993 (Decree 506/93). The major functions of SUP are to: (i) prepare policies for the development of universities and ensure that laws, regulations and norms are applied; (ii) define policies to assess the creation or the structural modification of curricula, programs or status and to accredit new institutions in the public and private sector; and (iii) design policies and instruments to assess and oversee the university system. Universities are autonomous institutions run by an elected council (Consejo Superior de la Universidad - CSU) consisting of representatives from faculty, administrative staff and students. Rectors are elected by an assembly comprised of the deans and faculty council for a period of three or four years. A National University Council (Consejo Interuniversitario Nacional - CIN) consists of representatives from national universities, and has been advising the MCE on education policy. 5.  1.13 The higher education system is almost entirely publicly financed. Students pay no tuition fees and external resources are limited (estimated to represent 8 percent of total resources on average). In 1994 consolidated public expenditure on higher education accounted for 0.91 percent of GDP and 22.8 percent of the consolidated budget for education. Higher education, like other sectors, was severely hit by the economic crisis and hyperinflation. The higher education budget in real terms peaked in 1987, and had been on the decline until 1992 (990 million pesos). As a consequence, per-student public expenditure dropped sharply from US$2,800 in 1983 to the very low level of US$1,450 per student in 1992 (in Brazil, Chile, and Mexico it ranges from US$1,600 to US$1,800). With the improvement of federal public finance this tendency has been reversed and per student public expenditure rose to 2.267 in 1994 (the budget was US$1,243 million in 1993, US$1,395 million in 1994 and US$1,501 million in 1995). However, this budget increase has been essentially absorbed by salary increases. At the university level this situation has led to budgets in which on the average 97 percent is absorbed by salaries and operating expenses, leaving only 3 percent available for investment and development. (Annex I, Graph 2). B. Main Issues in the Higher Education Sector Institutional Problems of Sector Management 1.14 The newly-created SUP does not yet have the full technical capacity to coordinate reform implementation, guide budget allocations, evaluate institutional performance and disseminate information for students and professors. Since its creation in March 1993, SUP has recruited 190 staff and filled all the positions in its organizational chart. However, the new staff needs training and technical assistance to acquire necessary planning and management tools. 1.15 Lack of reliable information hampers planning and management capacity. Until 1994, even basic information such as enrollment, number of entrants and graduates, composition of students by discipline and composition of staff was not available. Information is generally limited to that provided by national universities. As a result: (i) very little information is available on private universities and on non-university education; (ii) data are not collected regularly on a homogeneous basis; and (iii) the quality of data is not sufficient to be used for planning activities and more specifically, for allocation of resources or evaluation of output. For instance, no distinction between active and non-active students is made and no data are available on inputs such as teaching hours, student cost, social origin of the student population, or demand for higher education. 1.16 In the absence of accreditation and evaluation mechanisms there is little incentive for quality improvement. Before 1994, no programs or institutions (except on an experimental basis) were subject to any kind of formal evaluation. This does not allow for regular review and revision of existing curricula and methods of delivery, which consequently might remain unchanged for decades. In the future, this would limit the validity of any resource allocation system based on quality. Furthermore, there is no
 accreditation system for creating a new program or institution. Recently, a number of new programs, particularly at graduate levels, have been created in almost all the national universities without adequate control, leading to duplication in some disciplines and shortages in others. In addition, some new programs have been created without the resources needed (qualified instructors, basic research equipment, or adequate budget) to ensure minimum standards of quality. At the same time, once a program is established, it is not uncommon for it to remain even if there are no students. There is also a vacuum in the legislation for the newly-created private higher education institutions. 1.17 The higher education budget is inefficiently allocated, and largely beyond the control of the MCE. Since the creation of SUP, about eight percent of the total budget has been allocated to implement policies at the national level. The remaining 92 percent is still distributed between national universities through Congressional debate, which typically does not take into account data reflecting the specific situation of each university. There are no instruments or criteria on which decision-makers could rely to reorient the system toward more effective training, correct disparities, sanction poor performers or take into account sector-specific objectives in research or pedagogic enhancement. Consequently, disparities among institutions for the same kind of training are substantial, which leads to waste and inadequate distribution of resources, undermines efforts for improved management, and creates a disincentive for professors and students to perform well. 1.18 In most universities, governance mechanisms and management systems lack flexibility and the capacity to be efficient and adapt to a changing environment. On the one hand, decision-making in the Superior Council of the University (Consejo Superior de Universidad) is highly politicized and key managerial decisions are frequently disrupted by interest groups or ideological positions. In this often confrontational atmosphere, students who can get the majority of votes are often the strongest. On the other hand, many universities lack sufficient administrative tools and qualified personnel to produce timely and adequate information to make the managerial process more transparent. In generaL there are no clear objectives, development plans, or analytical allocation of resources between the different departments and no measurement of quality or efficiency. In addition, very few universities are able to mobilize external resources through tuition, sale of technology or other services, or joint ventures with private firms. Furthermore, since autonomy is only partial and the salary scale is standardized across the system, before the 1995 budget law universities were unable to provide incentives to promote efficiency among their staffs. Efficiency Issues 1.19 The internal efficiency of national universities is low and is declining. Available data indicate that only 19 percent of entrants actually graduate. In recent years the graduate/enrollment ratio has been below five percent (compared to Brazil, Chile or Mexico where the graduate/enrollment ratio ranges from 12 to 15 percent). This
 very low efficiency rate inflates the cost of producing a graduate to an estimated level of US$30,000. During the past decade the number of entrants and enrollment increased (at about 11 percent a year) while the increase in number of graduates nearly stagnated from 27,000 in 1981 to 32,000 in 1991; as a consequence the graduate enrollment ratio dropped from eight percent to five percent (see Annex I). About 55 percent of the students take less than 3 credits a year when they would need 4 or 5 for a normal duration of their study. The tendency to prolong the duration of study as well as to perpetuate low graduation rates is stronger among natural science and engineering disciplines and in smaller universities (see Annex 1, Table 4). 1.20 There are several causes of low internal efficiency. First, because of open access and low cost, a great proportion of secondary school graduates who are not motivated or well-prepared to enter higher education enroll in universities and drop out or repeat during the first year. Second, excessively rigid and uniform undergraduate course design, combined with inadequate curricula and teaching methods, do not meet the expectations of students. Third, teaching methods are further adversely affected by insufficient complementary resources including libraries, computers and technical equipment in laboratories or classrooms for practical work. Fourth, there are few financial or academic constraints to taking a light course load every year. Consequently, students tend to prolong their studies and a significant proportion of students have a full-time job during the day and take only night courses at the university. The last census revealed that about 54 percent of students have a job (30 percent having a full time job), and that 35 percent of students study less than 20 hours a week Quality Issues 1.21 In most universities the composition and qualification of faculty is insufflicient to ensure good quality teaching. During the past periods of dictatorship, Argentinean universities lost a number of scholars and have been unable to renew the pool of qualified professors. As a result, the qualifications of teaching staff are very low, only 15 percent of professors possessing a graduate degree. Poor compensation makes it extremely difficult to recruit and retain adequately qualified personnel in the system. Teaching staff, who are paid on a single public salary scale, are poorly compensated. Full- time professors on the average earn US$2,000 a month and teaching assistants, US$1,200. Furthermore, only 11 percent of the teaching staff consists of full-time professors, and the majority of teaching is carried out by teaching assistants or part-time professors. Because of low salaries, most staff undertake multiple jobs and often are not available to students outside the classroom, nor do they have time to undertake research. The lack of appropriate performance standards and evaluation methods does not provide incentives for quality improvement. 1.22 The present level of physical resources is insufficient to provide the university students with an adequate learning environment. The university system has been attempting to cope with decreasing financial resources from the government by cutting back on capital investment. Capital investment has been as low as 3 percent of total expenditures on education in recent years. As a result, learning and research
 materials and equipment have deteriorated and are a major constraint on improvement. Open-access libraries are insufficient and the number of volumes per student is low. Most of the existing technical equipment in laboratories is obsolete and teaching equipment is insufficient. The situation is particularly severe in the natural science and engineering fields, in which maintenance and constant renovation of equipment are necessary to keep up with progress in these disciplines. In general, buildings and equipment are insufficiently maintained. In some universities, several construction projects have not been completed because of lack of funding, and buildings have been left half-finished for a number of years. 1.23 In an environment in which universities do not have to compete for external resources, there is little incentive for them to diversify or introduce new programs which meet the needs of the economy. Except in very specific or vocational- oriented programs such as health, most universities have little interaction with the labor market. In general, there is no involvement of employers in program design or university management, there is no career counseling within universities, and the level of contracted activities with industry, be it for research, problem solving, or training, is very low. Little information is available to assess external efficiency, because of the absence of labor market or tracer studies of university graduates. Limited data on the labor market suggest unemployment among university graduates is lower than the general population (3.7 percent compared to 10.8 percent for the total population in 1994), probably because of the small number graduating every year and the strong demand of the economy for qualified people. This does not necessarily mean that those graduates correspond to the expectations of enterprises or that higher education contributes sufficiently to the country's ability in the long run to compete in international markets. C. Government Strategy Education Sector Strategy 1.24 To address the above issues, the Government has assigned high priority to the education sector with the aim of improving the coverage, quality and efficiency as well as the equity of education. The transfer of responsibility for secondary education to the provinces in 1992 (Law 24.049, January 1992) has changed the roles of the federal and the provincial governments, and has further stimulated the initiation of educational reforms. The first step in this strategy for reforming the educational sector was the passage of the comprehensive Federal Education Law (FEL, Law 24.195, April 1993) which sets out the objectives, structure, administration and financing mechanisms of the education system. More specifically, the FEL: (i) guarantees the right of Argentines to have access to education at all levels and establishes the principle of free basic education while allowing universities to supplement their publicly financed budget through other revenue sources; (ii) defines the responsibilities for providing educational services: provinces have the responsibility to finance and administer all pre-university education while the federal government provides policy guidance, establishes minimum curricular content at all levels and finances universities; (iii) defines the role of the private sector and its rights and obligations in providing educational services; (iv) establishes a new structure
 -9- for the education system which increases compulsory education from seven to 10 years (one year of preschool and nine years of general basic education), reducing the secondary school cycle to three years and reorienting it to a new curriculum integrating knowledge in four cluster areas (humanistic, social, scientific and technical); (v) for higher education, defines the respective roles of teacher training and technical institutes and universities; and (vi) stresses the importance of public investment in education, requiring that education budgets be either doubled gradually with an annual increase of 20 percent starting in 1993, or be increased by 50 percent as a share of GDP - i.e., from four percent to six percent of GDP - whichever results in a larger increase in the education budget. Higher Education Strategy 1.25 In higher education the Government strategy is to: (i) improve the legal and regulatory environment specifically for the creation of new institutions and programs in the private and public sectors, for university management and for quality evaluation; (ii) create incentives and support the initiatives and investments which could increase the efficiency and quality of universities; and (iii) improve the allocation of resources within universities and support the initiatives to diversify resources. A Higher Education Policy Letter which the Bank has received summarizes this strategy. 1.26 As part of this strategy, SUP has presented to Congress a Higher Education Law which: (i) specifies the conditions for students to gain access to higher education; (ii) assigns to the provinces the responsibility for non-university education (teacher training and technical institutes) and to the federal level the responsibility for universities; (iii) defines the objectives of higher education and the respective roles of each kind of institution, establishing a common legal framework for private and public institutions, including evaluation and accreditation; (iv) provides universities with full autonomy for their administration, internal resource allocation (including the creation of new programs and curriculum design), staff management, and conditions of student access, thus opening up the possibility for universities to diversify their resources; (v) improves the governance of higher education institutions, allowing more participation (a minimum of 50 percent) by teaching staff in elected boards and limiting students' right to vote to active students; and (vi) defines the roles of the federal government (for planning, financing and monitoring) and of the various consultative agencies (CIN, Consejo Interuniversitario Nacional; CRUP, Consejo de Rectores de Universidades Privadas; and Regional Councils for University Planning, Consejos de Planificacion Universitaria Regional). This law was adopted by the Chamber of Deputies on June 7, 1995. and is expected to be approved in 1995. A final vote of the Senate is expected shortly, which will enact the law. 1.27 Since its creation in March 1993, SUP has carried out measures which facilitate implementation of the higher education law, once passed: (i) as a first step to test the evaluation and accreditation process, nine universities and five post-graduate programs have been evaluated; (ii) an incentive system for teaching staff to undertake research was implemented for the first time in FY94 (11,500 professors have benefited, with a budget of US$42 million) and is being pursued in FY95 (with a budget of US$70 million); (iii) in 1994 a new student loan scheme was put in place which is managed by a commercial Bank
 - 10- instead of a Governmental institution, and the budget (US$10 million) was doubled in 1994; 1,300 students benefited from this program; (iv) most of the barriers to the creation of private higher education institutions were removed in 1993 by a decree (No. 2330), leading to the creation during the same year of 15 new institutions in addition to the existing 21; (v) initiatives have been taken in collaboration with the CIN to improve the curriculum (as a first step, a curriculum reform of engineering studies is under preparation which will reduce the duration of studies from six to five years and make the content more consistent from one university to another); (vi) the 1995 Budget law decentralizes to each university the decision of fixing the salary levels of their staff, (vii) a university management information system has been initiated by a May 1993 decree (Programa de Mejoramiento del Sistema de Informaci6n Universitaria - PMSlU), which has significantly expanded the availability of key sectoral information and includes a student census launched in September 1994, as well as a database on university personnel created in June 1994; and (viii) beginning in FY94 a share of the universities' budget is being allocated for investment through competitive mechanisms and through a formula which rationalizes allocations (equivalent to 1.57 percent of the total budget or about 40 percent of the universities' investment budget). D. Rationale for Bank Involvement and Lessons Learned from Previous Bank Experience Rationale for Bank Involvement 1.28 Bank involvement in the proposed project fully supports the overall country assistance strategy which was discussed at the Board on May 4, 1995: to sustain economic growth, to complete the reform of the state, enhance the competitiveness of the Argentine economy, reduce poverty, and improve the quality of human resource investment. The proposed project aims to: (i) improve the quality and efficiency of a sector which is key to maintaining competitiveness in an outward-oriented economy; (ii) complement the reform process of the education sector (supported for primary and secondary education by the Inter-American Development Bank (IDB) and the Bank, respectively) by rationalizing higher education spending and helping to channel more resources to basic and secondary education; and (iii) strengthen the greatly weakened institutional base and helping the government to overcome difficulties of introducing reforms in a highly complex sector. This project will assure the continuation and consolidation of initiatives and reforms already undertaken by the Argentinean Government. Furthermore, the project will establish permanent mechanisms which will ensure sustainable improvement of the higher education system. Lessons Learned 1.29 The project incorporates lessons learned in recent lending operations in Argentina's social sectors, including the Social Sector Management Technical Assistance Loan (Ln. 2985-AR, approved in 1989) the Maternal and Child Health and Nutrition Project (Ln. 3643-AR, approved in 1993), and Decentralization and Improvement of Secondary Education Project (Ln. 3794-AR, approved in 1994). The
 - 11 - factors affecting projects in Argentina are essentially: (i) institutional weaknesses; (ii) lack of political commitment to fulfill the objectives of the project; and (iii) implementation delays caused by unfamiliarity with Bank procedures, common in social sectors in which investment projects are relatively new. The case of Argentina confirms lessons learned from Bank projects in the education sector: (i) institution - building should remain a central goal of Bank assistance; (ii) success depends on effective policy dialogue and sound implementation procedures; (iii) experience with project implementation confirms the advantage of simple projects with realistic time schedules and appropriate covenants; and (iv) the project should include appropriate monitoring and evaluation, so that progress toward goals can be assessed. 1.30 Other lessons of experience have been identified in higher education projects. More specifically: (i) the failure to understand the complex, unique and autonomous nature of universities and the potential impact of their internal politics on the project; (ii) the need to implement changes gradually by reaching consensus on reforms, creating a more competitive environment at the same time by providing incentives for improvement; and (iii) an insufficient assessment of the links with the labor market due to the absence of comprehensive labor market data. The Argentinean higher education reforms are in line with the sector policy reforms as recommended in the Bank's policy paper on Higher Education: The Lessons of Experience (Development in Practice, World Bank, May 1994) and include measures to: (i) allocate public resources to higher education transparently and in ways that strengthen quality and increase efficiency; (ii) introduce cost-sharing and other financial diversification measures; (iii) establish a positive environment for private institutions; (iv) provide autonomy for higher education institutions in how they raise and use resources and determine student intake; and (v) increase the quality of training and research by increased teaching inputs, teacher training, and mechanisms to evaluate and monitor the quality of training and research outputs. In addition, the design of the project takes account of the experience of similar higher education projects in Indonesia, Romania, and Tunisia, as well as the implementation of the Second Science Research and Training Project (Ln. 3269-BR) in Brazil. 1.31 The following lessons have been incorporated into the proposed project at the initial phase of its design: (i) Project Ownership: The sense of project ownership in SUP is strong because the scope and content of the proposed project fully support its policy orientations and reflect its initial proposal. Considerable attention was paid during the preparation process to extending this sense of ownership to universities and the academic community: (a) there has been a strong participation of professors and deans in the various studies and consultative committees; (b) universities have volunteered to participate in the evaluation process; and (c) each component of the project was agreed with the CIN and at appraisal the final project was discussed with all the rectors; (ii) Project Design: Project design emphasizes a greater reliance on incentive instruments to implement policies. The experience of OECD countries shows that the behavior of autonomous universities can be influenced most effectively by improving the availability of information and modifying the way resources are allocated. Therefore, the proposed project relies heavily on two instruments: (a) an information and evaluation system that provides transparent and objective information to the different actors - students, managers and teachers; and (b) an
 - 12 - allocation system which provides incentives for efficiency, thus creating a more competitive environment; (iii) Institutional Weakness and Project Implementation: From the earliest stage, the preparation process has aimed for the creation of a strong institutional base backed by the borrower's full cooperation and involvement. The PPF approved for project preparation (see also para 3.7) has largely contributed to the strengthening of SUP technical capacities, helping it to bridge the time necessary for SUP to recruit staff. In implementing the PPF the staff of the PPU has gained considerable experience in Bank procedures (especially procurement, disbursements, and the management of a Special Account). To ensure continuity the same PPU will be transformed into a Project Implementation Unit located within SUP. In addition, most of the tasks included in the first component aimed at institutional strengthening have been initiated during the preparation process. Finally, to facilitate project implementation and disbursement, much attention was given to the simplification of project design.

 - 33 - IV. BENEFITS AND RISKS A. Benefits 4.1 The project would consolidate difficult sector reforms and provide incentives for universities to increase their investment in graduate education. In addition, the efficiency gains in higher education will facilitate a greater concentration of resources on basic and secondary education. More specifically, the project would improve the efficiency and quality of the university system by: (i) increasing the transparency and accountability of resource allocation and use; (ii) introducing competition among universities in gaining access to funding for research and teaching activities; (iii) revising curricula; (iv) promoting the restructuring of graduate education by strengthening, in each discipline, only a limited number of centers of excellence with a critical mass (about 200 out of 767 graduate programs); (v) training about 3000 professors (an increase of more than 50 percent of the current potential with Ph.D degrees) as well as increasing teaching staff mobility; and (vi) providing laboratory and teaching equipment, corresponding to 40 percent of potential needs in order to increase the quality of experimental teaching. B. Risks 4.2 The first risk concems the implementation of the legal framework for reforms which supports the project. Political tensions are traditionally high in the university sector and universities are autonomous institutions that usually resist change. This risk has been minimized recently and should not directly affect the implementation of the project. First, the legal framework as well as the project content has been largely discussed by the Govemment through an intense public debate. Since 1994, the Govemment has shown a strong and constant commitment to the reform process, demonstrated by the adoption of the Higher Education Law by the Chamber of Deputies on June 7, 1995. There is also a consensus among rectors on the objectives and major components of the project, and CIN and CRUP, which have been fully involved during the preparation process, will be represented in the institutional structure of CONEAU and FOMEC. Second, this new legal framework confirms and fosters changes which have already taken place in the higher education policy and in some universities: (i) the autonomy of universities was confirmed in the Constitution adopted in August 1994 and the 1995 budget law; (ii) private university development was liberalized by a decree in 1993; (iii) the 1992 financial administration law authorizes universities to diversify resources; (iv) some universities, through foundations or "cooperadoras," are already collecting student fees and contracting with enterprises; these resources represent US$100 million or 6.6 percent of their total income; (v) the evaluation and accreditation system is already being implemented by the CNA; and (vi) about 25 percent of public universities are currently implementing an admissions procedure for entry into undergraduate programs.
 - 34 - 4.3 The second risk concerns the fact that FOMEC is a new institution. In order to minimize the risk of irregularities in the selection of sub-projects and funding procedures of FOMEC: (i) an annual physical and financial external audit would be undertaken; (ii) once a year, CIS would evaluate the results of FOMEC operations and their impact on quality and efficiency improvement in universities; review the institutional performance of FOMEC; verify the transparency and objectivity of the selection procedure; and formulate concrete recommendations; and (iii) a Mid-Term Review would define, if necessary, any changes in financial and institutional arrangements. C. Sustainability 4.4 Operating costs, which represent only 4.7 percent of total project cost, are supported by the Government. Most of the permanent staff who will be involved in the management of the project are part of the new organizational structure of SUP (which includes 192 staff) determined by law. The institutional development of CONEAU and FOMEC would play a critical role in ensuring continuity of quality control and competitive funding in support of university education. The institutional stability of the project will be assured by the formal establishment (by enabling decrees) of CONEAU and FOMEC prior to negotiations. In addition, to ensure the financial sustainability of FOMEC, SUP will allocate to FOMEC US$70 million, representing the share of the FY95 university budget devoted to the incentive program for teaching staff to undertake research. The objective is to make FOMEC a permanent funding mechanism by progressively increasing the annual national funding by US$30 million by the end of the project in 2001. In addition, the budgetary process itself ensures that the universities' counterpart funding for FOMEC will be available. In fact, by allocating the federal budget to each university on a monthly basis, SUP can link FOMEC financing to the availability of counterpart funding. D. Poverty Category 4.5 The project has no direct impact on poverty alleviation. However, the resulting efficiency gains from the reform of the financing system could reduce the growth of public higher education expenditures, and therefore contribute to an overall environment in which more resources are available for secondary education, a major source of inequity. E. Environmental Impact 4.6 The project does not present environmental risks and has an environmental rating of "C." Increased capacity in basic sciences and engineering disciplines might impact favorably on the development of environmental teaching and research. The operating guidelines of FOMEC will stipulate that all activities to be funded must comply with prevailing rules for environmental preservation.

doc.abstracts: The Higher Education Reform Project will establish a competitive environment for the improvement of higher education and to provide, through a transparent funding mechanism, the appropriate incentives for continuous educational efficiency gains and quality enhancement. The project will support the implementation of legal, management and administrative reforms that the Secretariat of University Policy (SUP) has recently initiated in the university system. Thus, the project will have a: (1) institutional strengthening component; and (2) Fund for Enhancement of Educational Quality (Fondo de Mejoramiento de la Calidad, FOMEC) component.
